titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. At 4 this afternoon was a meeting of the Historical Society, which I attended. I presented to the Society seven volumes of the Journals of the House of Representatives under the Provincial Government, and also a
a copy of the Conquest of Canaan. Some other Communications were made— The meeting dissolved between 5 and 6.— This morning Dr: Cutler and Judge Davis called upon me, to look at the Flora Batava which I received a few days ago, for the American Academy— I agreed this morning with Mr: John Odin, to sell him my house in Hanover Street, where I now dwell— I am to give him the deed and possession, on the 1st: of next month.

2. Dined at Mr: W. Smith’s, with Mr: and Mrs: J. Sheaffe of Portsmouth; Mr: Nichols, and a young Mr: Swett of Newbury-Port— In the evening I attended a meeting of the Stockholders of the Fire and Marine Insurance Company, to choose a President and Directors— Those of the last year were rechosen— With T. K. Jones, instead of J. Codman deceased— A statement of the Company’s Affairs was laid before the Stockholders. The dividend was 20 per Cent.

3. Dined at Mr: Quincy’s; with Mr: Allyn of Duxbury and Dr: Elliot— This afternoon between 5 and 6 I went to Quincy, with Mr: Gardner— W. Shaw went out with Dexter— Found my mother, a little better; so as to give us some hopes of her recovery.

4. Heard Mr: Pipon, of Taunton; in the forenoon upon Hope— Afternoon upon filial Affection. Mr: Beale, and my Uncle Adams spent the Evening with us.— Read little; and wrote nothing— Dr: Welsh here at dinner, and to pass the Night.

5. Return’d with Dr: Welsh and Mr: Shaw, this morning to Boston— Wrote letters to Mr: Hellen, and to B. Pickman junr:— At tea, with Mrs: Adams, Caroline and the children at Mr: W. Sullivan’s— Mr: Hall there; came home and spent an hour with us.

6. Mrs: Adams, and the child, went out with me to Quincy— My object was to attend on a Committee Of the Court of Sessions, to view the spot where a road is petitioned for— It goes through part of my land— Just as we reached my father’s house it began to rain with all the appearance of a storm. I went with my father to Newcomb’s tavern where the Committee were assembled. They adjourned untill half past two, and we return’d to dinner— The afternoon was fair, and we went over the ground with the Committee— I left them at about 5 and with my wife and child came home— The evening was so cold as to require a fire— The annual meeting of the proprietors of Neponsit Bridge; and also a meeting of the Directors was this day held in Boston; which I could not attend. The Directors of the last year were rechosen.

7. Weather so cold, we had a fire the whole day— I attempted to do some business, but without success. Mr: Dexter and his lady call’d on us this afternoon, to invite us on Friday Evening to tea, with Genl: Smith who is in town.— Club this Evening at Mr: Amory’s— Thin.

8. Our youngest child continues quite unwell— Dr: Welsh here this Evening— I began this day to make preparations for our removal.— Mr: Pickman called upon me this morning, and we agreed that I should take up my note to him, the first of next month— I saw Mr: Morrill, and desired him if he could, to let, my pew in the first church. Dr: Jackson called on me, to mention that the Society for the Study of Natural Philosophy, had elected Dr: Howard, as a member— I told him that I was much
much pleased with the choice; though I could scarce have a right to a vote, as being under the necessity of leaving the town, and of course the Society— He said there would be a meeting to-morrow evening, at Mr: Quincy’s; but being engaged at Mr: Dexter’s I cannot attend it.

I have read Le Belier, and Fleur d’Epine of Count Antoine Hamilton, an Irishman by birth, attached to James 2.’s Court, in his exile, and who wrote french with the utmost purity and elegance of style— These two works are fairy tales, at once in imitation of and a satyre upon the Arabian Nights. There appears much resemblance between the manner of this writer, and. that of the younger Crebillon. Wieland the German imitates them— But Hamilton is never indecent, which cannot be said of either of the others— The name of Tarare, as a character, is in Fleur d’Epine, the hero of the tale— This name, Beaumarchais has adapted to another Story.

9. Called at Mr: Quincy’s Office, and settled with him the action of Mr: Murray, against the President and Directors of the Union Bank— Remainder of the day did little or nothing— Evening at Mr: Dexter’s, at Roxbury— Caroline went with me; but Mrs: Adams could not leave her child— General Smith, and his family, Mr: Mason and his family, Mr: & Mrs: George Blake, Mr: & Miss Sumner were the Company.

10. I shall henceforth have no other occupation than to make preparations for our departure— I purchased two shares in the Neponsit Bridge Corporation of Mr: K. Whitman— Went out to Quincy in the Stage this afternoon— Took George with me.

11. Heard Mr: Whitney. Read a few letters of Madame de Sevigné, and spent the leisure part of the day, in looking over the fruit and kitchen garden— I brought out for my father Forsyth’s treatise upon the management of fruit-trees.

12. Return’d to Boston this morning; my Sister Smith came with me; and went back to Quincy this afternoon— Mr: Foster call’d on me, and I settled my assessments on my Neponsit-Bridge shares, up to the October assessment inclusive— Pass’d the evening at Mr: B. Welles’s with a Company of about 40. ladies and Gentlemen— General Smith & Mr: Breck were there, with their families.

13. Employed very busily the whole day in packing up books, and preparing to quit the house— Mr: Boylston called upon me— I paid Mr: William Pickman for his brother part of my note due to him— For the remainder, my house must pay.— Read one Act of The Winter’s Tale, and part of Florian’s Estelle.

14. Continued all day in the same employment as yesterday— As the time of departure approaches I find myself pressed for want of time— My papers are in some Confusion. After I return’d from Europe, I spent one fortnight at Quincy, solely putting in order my papers letter &c belonging to the 7. years I had been abroad— Those papers therefore are perfectly well sorted— And they are the only papers I have in that situation— I never spent any time more profitably— Club this evening at Judge Dawes’s, instead of Judge Davis’s, he being at Salem— It was not fully attended— Mr: Bronson there.

15. This morning at 7. two Carts came in from Quincy, which we loaded, one with books and the other with furniture, and sent them out about 2. in the afternoon. They are to come in again next Tuesday, for two loads more. Continued packing— Caroline and Mr: Shaw pass’d the Evening at Mr: Sumner’s in Roxbury.

16. Continued employed as before. Finished this day the packing of my books. Sold Mr: Boylston One Share of the Neponsit Bridge Corporation. N: 56.— Read Florian’s Estelle, and some small poems in the same volume.

17. I purchased some shares in the New-England Insurance Company, after having endeavoured yesterday to procure some without success— Was busied still in preparations for my departure. Wrote to Coll: Pope at New-Bedford to inquire for a vessel going to Baltimore— Also to Coll: Jos: May, Secretary to the Assistant fire Society, requesting them as I am about to remove from the town, to erase my name from their list of members— This was the day of quarterly meeting; and they dined at Watertown; I intended to have gone out, but could get no opportunity for a conveyance. In the afternoon I went out with Dexter to Quincy— Pass’d over the new road as far as the bridge.

18. Heard Mr: Thomas of Scituate, whom I did not know— Find my mother, God be praised, much better. Spent the leisure part of my time, chiefly in arranging and sorting my letters and papers received since I have been in America. Read a few letters of Sevigne; and walk’d with my father over his grounds, to examine the fruit— Spent the Evening with him.

19. Return’d to Boston early this morning— We this day pack’d up all our glass and China-Ware. I made out several Accounts and arranged papers— Conversation with Quincy at noon; and when he called upon me this Evening— Political, and particular.

20. Mr: Briesler, came in from Quincy, and assisted us in packing— I dined at Mr: Quincy’s with a small company of Gentlemen— Judge Benson of New-York was there; and we sat very late. Coll: Bradford attempted a sale of five Middlesex Canal Shares, but could not effect it.

21. Still employed the whole day in packing and arranging papers. Mr: Gurley and Mr: Andrew Dexter called upon me, respecting the lease of my house in Court Street— Mr: Gurley, who has forfeited the lease, by a breach of its agreements on his part, is about to leave the State and remove to New-Orleans; and has undertaken to make an assignment of his lease over to Mr: Dexter, without consulting me; I informed him I should not consent to this, and that he must make some new agreement with me, or I should enter upon the estate, as under a forfeiture of the lease— We had much discussion but came to no terms— Mr: Odin called upon me— He is to have my deed, and to pay me the money next Monday— The club this evening was at Dr: Dexter’s— I attended, for the last time in all probability.— Executed power of attorney, and affidavit against effects of Bird, Savage & Bird.

22. Mr: Mitchell and Thomas came early this morning with their Carts, and took two more loads of our furniture out to Quincy. We were busy in loading them all the morning— About 2. P.M. they went away— I wrote a letter to Mr: S. Williams in London, to enclose my power of attorney to him, and my affidavit of debt due me by Bird, Savage and Bird, to send by Mr: B. Welles. Attended a meeting of the Committee of publications of the American Academy, and took up with me, the Papillons d’Europe, to present to the Academy.— Dr: Lathrop, Dr: Warren, and Dr: Kirkland were there— Met Mr: Townsend— This afternoon I sent him several papers, for the Court at Dedham next week, and two deeds to be recorded there.— Tea, and pass’d the Evening, with my wife,
her sister Caroline, the two children and Mr: Shaw, at Mr: Quincy’s— He was out at the Bridge, and came home late; having broken down with his carriage— Mr: Chevreau, the Roman Catholic clergyman was there.

23. Wrote a number of letters on the business of the Academy— Delivered one of thanks to Mr: Winthrop, who tells me he has found where the place called Naumeag was— I called on Mr: Gurley; and looked over the alterations he has made in my house— We could not agree upon any terms— Went out with Mr: Otis—(H. G.) and dined with Mr: Boylston—Mr: Mc:Donogh—Dr: Warren and his son, and Mr: Mair were there— Returned home between 7 and 8 in the evening— Recd: a letter from Coll: Pope— New Bedford—

24. This day, Mrs: Adams and the family were to have quitted the house in Boston, and gone out to Quincy; but we could not accomplish all our preparations for departure; they concluded to stay untill Monday, and I went out in the Carriage, with Dexter, alone— I was engaged the greatest part of the day, in making my final arrangements, and in endeavouring to come to a settlement with Mr: Gurley— I called on Mr: Parsons, whom Gurley has employed as Counsel— We finally agreed to refer the decision of our questions to Coll: T. H. Perkins; and signed an agreement to that effect.

25. Heard a young Mr: Lincoln— Employed all the leisure part of the day in arranging papers, and in making records of the American Academy, as Corresponding Secretary— Collected together all my letters, letter-books, Journals and Diaries, which I have deposited, in a large trunk, in my father’s Office.

26. The two Carts went to Boston again this day, and brought away, all the remainder of our furniture. It was between 4 and 5 in the afternoon, before they were entirely loaded, and it then began to rain. In coming out, several of the articles got damaged by the rain. I went into Boston very early in the morning— Called on Mr: Babcock, and left his papers: with him but he was not at home— He called afterwards on me, and paid me my account— I saw Coll: Perkins’s at his store— He declined deciding our questions alone— We afterwards agreed to join Mr: T. Davis, and Captn: D. Sargent junr: with him— They met at Vila’s this afternoon, between 5 and 6. heard us, untill past 8. and made their award— In the mean time, my house had been thoroughly cleared— Mrs: Adams with Caroline, two maids, and the two children went out to Quincy, in the Carriage— I was to have taken out Betsey Newcomb, but finding myself detained so late; and that it rained, I sent her down to lodge at Whitcomb’s, and went and ask’d a bed for myself at Mr: Smith’s— Mr: Shaw, had kept his bed, and chamber in the house— In addition to the other business, I this day delivered the deed of the house to Mr: Odin, and assigned over the policy to him. Received payment of it from him— Paid my note to B. Pickman junr: and took it up— Coll: Bradford sold two of my father’s Middlesex Canal Shares, at Auction—at 18/1 to the pound— They were bought by J. Jackson.

27. I went down to my late house this morning, and cleared off every thing that had remained behind. Received the award of the referees in my case with Mr: Gurley. They have increased his rent 100 dollars a year— We made an endorsement on the lease, conformable to their award. I paid Mr: B. Hall, my Assessments on my Canal Shares, and on the two to be transferr’d by my father— Went with Judge Davis to the Academy’s Room in the State-House, and took some blank circular letters— Dined at Mr: Smith’s, and between 4 and 5 in the afternoon; I took up Betsey Newcomb at Whitcomb’s, and came out to Quincy; thus terminating my second residence in Boston, which has lasted, almost two years.

28. I went to Boston again this morning— Louisa Smith went with me. Delivered J. Jackson the Certificates of Canal Shares, transferred by my father, and received payment. Deposited in the Union Bank the exact sum, to settle my father’s Account— Deposited in the Branch Bank, for safe keeping, a small red trunk, containing an hundred Eagles, and my important securities of property— I dined at Whitcomb’s— Called in the afternoon on Mr: Otis, who agreed to go with us— On Saturday, to Providence— Whitcomb furnishes the Carriage and Horses— I received from Mrs: Johnson a letter with the unpleasant information that Mr: Hellen, has lost his youngest child: he died the 19th: instt:— We returned to Quincy early this Evening.

29. Spent the day, in arranging my books and papers at Quincy, and in writing letters, as Corresponding Secretary to the American Academy— Dr: Tufts, with his wife, and daughter in Law, were here this afternoon, and at tea. Settled accounts with my father, and gave him a check on the Union Bank for the balance.

30. R. Dexter went into Boston, and received the balance from the Union Bank— Return’d this afternoon, and brought me letters from Mr: Pitcairn— I went up with the ladies successively to Mr: Cranch’s— Afterwards down to Mitchell’s, and again to Mr: Cranch’s where I pass’d part of the evening— Everett came out this evening, with a Carriage and four horses to take us to Providence to-morrow; Mr: Shaw came out with him. Mr: Otis, will meet us at Milton.

Day. On the eve of removing and of taking a journey, my manner of living has not been settled or regular enough for any general statement in this particular. I have now closed my residence in Boston; probably for several years— Perhaps forever— It has like every other period of my life had its pleasures and its pains— The transition from the station and the means of expence I had previously possessed, could not be agreeable; yet I found it less mortifying than might be expected, and easily reconciled my mind to it— I have practiced all the economy I thought practicable, but have needed still more— My accounts I have kept very regularly and have ascertained the expence at which I could live in Boston as I have lived.— I fix it at $2400 a year, besides house-rent, which may be valued at $600 more. My business has given me about $1000; but by some successful dispositions of property, and with the income, I have derived from the Estate I had, my capital has remained unimpaired: it has however remained equally unimproved, and as to the amount of my possessions, I am just where I was two years ago—
